titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Jisr az-Zarqa Arabic
titleStmt.author: Gunda Kinzl

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: Carmel Coast dialect with Bedouin influences
Ǧisir iz-Zarga is the only town in Israel on the Mediterranean coast with an exclusively Arab populace. It gets its name from the Wadi az-Zarqa/Taninim river.

The people of Ǧisir belong to three or four main tribes who each have their own oral history of ancestry. At least two different dialects are spoken according to Jastrow, confirmed by Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger. The ˁAmmāš and Ǧurbān claim that they came to Ǧisir from the Jordan Valley (ġōr). Indeed, a tribe or tribal confederation called the Ġawārna (sing. Ġōrānī) is found along the river Jordan and in the Galilee, and allegedly they settled also in li-Mqēble and Ǧisir. On the other hand, a geographical depression or swamp is called ġōr, typically a less desired portion of land, and historically often riddled with Malaria. Thus, the term may regardless of ancestry have been employed in a derogatory manner to denote the “people of the swamps”. Some outsiders even referred to the people of Ǧisir as ġaǧar, “gypsies”. They are described as particularly dark-skinned.

The Šihāb and Naǧǧār tribes possibly came to Ǧisir from Egypt or the Sudan, although the Naǧǧār claim Maghrebinian ancestry according to Jastrow. Geva-Kleinberger in personal correspondence states that they came to historic Palestine from Upper Egypt with Napoleon Bonaparte’s army in the early 19th century.

Their alleged collaboration with Israel in the first Arab-Israeli war in 1948 has allowed Ǧisir’s citizens to stay in their village when most other villages in the area were destroyed, save for two others (Fradīs and Mifǧar, the latter later replaced by a power station). They were indispensable as workers and had helped drain the swamps in the coastal area as they were more resilient to Malaria.

Ǧisir az-Zarqa is a very poor town, crowded due to several factors preventing its expansion: The sea to the west, the Haifa-Tel Aviv road to the east, a natural reserve and the kibbutz Ma'agan Michael to the north and a dirt wall that separates it from the affluent Cesarea neighbourhood, built to keep out the sound of the muezzin and of celebrations on one hand and burglars from Ǧisir iz-Zarga on the other.
Opportunities are limited for the inhabitants of Ǧisir, half of which are below the age of 19, although there are some hopeful initiatives in place to revive the area as a tourist destination.

There are several mentions of the dialect of the Ġawārna, but these studies deal with widely different areas. It remains unclear to what extent the Ġawārna had or still have a common dialect. For information on the Ġawārna, see Bergsträßer 1915 and El-Kayed Bani Yasin’s 1980 doctoral thesis. Rosenhouse 1984a and 1984b are a good overview of the Bedouin dialects in northern Israel mentioning the Ġawārna and also contain extralinguistic information.

Most importantly, Jastrow 2009 deals with Ǧisir. He distinguishes between a Ǧisir I and Ǧisir II dialect and places them within the group of “Carmel Coast dialects”, distinct from the dialects of the Muṯallaṯ.

Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger in their excellent Atlas of the Arabic dialects of Galilee (Israel) take over Jastrow’s classification. It contains Jastrow’s material as well as own data on both Ǧisir I and II.
